Corsica, indeed, suf- fered a sudden convulsion from the teme- rity of the governor. The name of this officer was Decimus Pacarius. Though the island, in a war carried on by such powerful adversaries, was of no impor- tance, he endeavoured to seduce the in- habitants to the interest of Vitellius. The project, which would have decided no- thing, ended in his own ruin. He sum- moned a council of the leading men, and communicated his design. Claudius Phir- ricus, who commanded the galleys on that station, and Quinctius Certus, a Roman knight, objected to the measure, and were put to instant death. The rest of the as- sembly, terrified by this act of violence, swore fidelity to Vitellius. The populace, as usual, blind and ignorant, but by con- tagion catching the fears of others, fol- lowed the example of the leading chiefs. Pacarius began to muster his men, and train them to the use of arms. A race of rude and vulgar peasants, who had no re- lish for the fatigue of military discipline,
